content:
Yes, the Dutch faced frequent resistance from the local population, especially in the later period of their colonial rule. The oppression of the Cultivation System, coupled with high taxation and forced labor, led to frequent uprisings and rebellions by the local population.

One of the most significant rebellions was the Java War of 1825-1830, which was sparked by the imposition of compulsory coffee cultivation and taxes. The rebellion was led by Prince Diponegoro and resulted in the deaths of thousands of people on both sides.

Other notable uprisings include the Aceh War (1873-1908), in which the Acehnese in Sumatra resisted Dutch attempts to impose colonial rule, and the Bali Wars (1846-1849 & 1906), where the Balinese resisted Dutch attempts to convert them to Christianity and Westernize their culture.

Overall, the Dutch faced significant opposition from the local population throughout their colonial rule, but they were able to maintain control through a combination of military force, economic domination, and political manipulation.
